resources.string: Follow the instructions below for every oral drug to be given at home. Also follow the instructions listed with each drug\'s dosage table.\n

• Determine the appropriate drugs and dosage for the child's weight and age.
• Tell the mother the reason for giving the drug to the child.
• Demonstrate how to measure a dose.
• Watch the mother practise measuring a dose by herself.
• Ask the mother to give the first dose to the child.
• Explain carefully how to give the drug, then label and package the drug.
• If more than one drug will be given, collect, count and package each drug separately.
• Explain that all the oral drug tablets or syrups must be used to finish the course of treatment, even if the child gets better.
• Check the mother\’s understanding before she leaves the clinic.

• Explain to the mother what the treatment is and why it should be given.
• Describe the treatment steps listed in the appropriate box.
• Watch the mother as she gives the first treatment in the clinic (except remedy for cough or sore throat).
• Explain to the mother how often to give the treatment at home.
• If needed for treatment at home, give mother the tube of tetracycline ointment or a small bottle of gentian violet.
• Check the mother\’s understanding before she leaves the clinic.

• Clean both eyes 3 times daily: 

		• Wash hands.
		• Ask child to close the eye.
		• Use clean cloth and water to gently wipe away pus from inside out.


• Then apply tetracycline eye ointment in both eyes 3 times daily.

		• Ask the child to look up.
		• Squirt a small amount of ointment on the inside of the lower lid.
		• Wash hands again.

• Treat until redness is gone.

• Do not use other eye ointments or drops, or put anything else in the eye.

• Dry the ear at least three times daily.

		• Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
		• Place the wick in the child's ear.
		• Remove the wick when wet.
		• Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.

• Treat the mouth ulcers twice daily: 

		• Wash hands.
		• Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt and water.
		• Paint the mouth with half-strength gentian-violet.
		• Wash hands again.

• Clean the mouth as for mouth ulcers.
• instill Nystatin 1ml 4 times a day or treat with GV and avoid feeding for 20 minutes after medication.
• If breastfed advise mother to wash her breasts after feeds and apply the same medicine on the areola.
• If severe reccurent or pharyngeal thrush refer for HIV testing.

• Safe remedies to recommend: 
		-Breastmilk for breastfeeding children.
 		-Warm water with lemon and honey (children > 6 months)
• Harmful remedies to discourage: 
 		-Codeine and ephedrine containing cough mixtures.

• If BCG not given at birth, it should not be given to children with symptomatic HIV /AIDS.
• Measles vaccine at 6 months is for HIV exposed /infected children.
• Yellow fever vaccine should not be given to children with symptomatic HIV /AIDS.
• Yellow fever vaccine is only offered in (Koibatek, Baringo, Keiyo) in Rift valley.
• Rota virus vaccine-should not be given to children over 15 months.

resources.string: • Make sure a child with any general danger sign is referred: \n \t - After first dose of appropriate antibiotic and other urgent treatments.\n \t - Exception: Rehydration of the child according to Plan C may resolve danger signs so that referral is no longer needed.

Key Elements of IMCI
1. Assessment
 	Assess for general danger signs (or possible bacterial infection in a young infant), common illnesses and other health problems.

 2. Classification

3. Identify Treatment
  Helps health workers to quickly and accurately identify treatment as per each classification. If a child has more than one classification, the health worker must look at more than one table to find the appropriate treatments.

 
 4. Treat
 Shows how to administer treatment for identified classifications. It shows those requiring admissions or referral specific treatment and advice on home care.

 
 5. Counsel
  Teach the mother when to return to the clinic if follow up is indicated and recognize signs that indicate that the child should be brought back to the clinic immediately.

 
 6. Follow up
  Children requiring to be seen again are identified and brought back to the clinic, appropriate follow up care is offered and reassessed for any new problems.
Age up to 2 months
Age 2 months up to 5 years
Proceed

Ask questions about how mother cares for her child as below:
 Ask:
• How do you play with your child?
• How do you communicate with your child?

resources.string:
Give all missed doses on this visit.

• Include sick babies and those with no records(mother child health booklet) or evidence.
• If the infant has no booklet, issue a new one today.
• Advise the mother when to return for the next vaccination.

1. Determine whether it is the initial visit or just a follow up of an illness

 2. If it is a follow up head to Treatment Chart in the Treat Child Tab

 3. If it is an initial visit assess the child as follow

ASSESSMENT

 Ask the mother what the child's problems are 
 		 1. Determine whether it is the initial visit or just a follow up of an illness if it is a follow up use the follow up button on the mainmenu.
 if it is an initial visit assess the child as follow: 
 ---

If the child is on the initial visit. 

Ask: 
	 • Is the child able to drink or breastfeed?
	 • Does the child vomit everything? 
	 • Has the child had convulsions? 
 
 Look: 

	 • See if child is lethargic or unconscious 
	 • Is the child convulsing now ? 
 If yes treat immediately.
Check for general danger signs
Determine if this is an initial or follow-up visit for this problem \n
if follow up Click HERE
\t - If it is an initial visit, assess the young infant as follows: \n

Does the child have Cough or difficult breathing ?
 IF YES ASK 
 For how long?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
• Count the breaths in one minute.
• Look for chest indrawing.
• Look and listen for stridor.
• Look and listen for wheeze.

Child must be calm
 IF CHILD IS: 
 • 2 months up to 12 months fast breathing is 50 breaths per minute or more.
• 12 months up to 5 years fast breathing is 40 breaths per minute or more.
 PLEASE CLASSIFY IF IT'S A COUGH OR DIFFICULT BREATHING

Does the child have diarrhoea?
 
 FOR HOW LONG?
 Is there blood in the stool?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Look at the child’s general condition.
• Is the child: Lethargic or unconscious?
 Is the child restless and irritable?
• Look for sunken eyes.
• Offer the child fluid. Is the child not able to drink or drinking poorly?
• Pinch the skin of the abdomen. Does it go back: 
Very slowly(SEVERE DEHYDRATION) (longer than 2 sec.), 
Slowly(SOME DEHYDRATION), 
Immediately(NO DEHYDRATION)?


 PLEASE CLASSIFY FOR: 1.DEHYDRATION 
2.DIARRHOEA FOR 14 DAYS OR MORE(PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA) 
3.IF BLOOD IN THE STOOL(DYSENTRY)

Does the child have fever?
 IF YES ASK 
 Has the child travelled to a high risk Malaria area in the last one month ?
 THEN ASK: 
 For how long?
 If more than 7 days , has fever been present every day?
 Has the child had signs of measles within the last 3 months?

 LOOK AND FEEL
 • Look and feel for stiff neck.
• Look for runny nose.
• Look for signs of measles …generalized rash and one of these runny nose, cough or red eyes.
 

 DO A MALARIA TEST
 IF Test is Positive
 P.falciparum PRESENT
 P.vivax PRESENT
 ELSE 
 P.falciparum ABSENT
 P.vivax ABSENT
 

NOTE: if you can’t test, don’t withhold treatment

Check for complications of Measles
 • Look for mouth ulcers, are they deep or extensive?
• Look for pus draining from the eye.
• Look for clouding of their cornea.
 CLASSIFICATIONS 
 1.High malaria risk
 2.Low malaria risk
 3.Measles

IF YES ASK 
 Is there ear pain?
 Is there ear discharge? If yes, how long?
 LOOK, AND FEEL 
 • Look for pus draining from the ear.
• Feel for tender swelling behind the ear? 

 Classify EAR PROBLEM

ASK: Is there history of TB contact?

 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Take the child\’s weight and plot it against mother / child health booklet to determine the z-score.
• Take the child\’s length/height for age and plot on mother /child health booklet to determine the z_score.
• Determine the growth pattern: is the growth faltering?(Weight curve is flattening or dropping for at least 2 consecutive months? )
• Look for oedema of both feet
• Look for visible severe wasting.

 For children aged 6 months up to 59 months, determine MUAC: 
• < 11.5cm
• 11.5 - 12.5cm
• 12.5 - 13.5cm
 Determine Z score for the same : 
• <-3
• -3 to < -2
• -2 to < -1
• -1 to +2

Look for palmar pallor, is it: 
• Severe palmar pallor?
• Some palmar pallor?
• No palmar pallor?

CHECK FOR HIV EXPOSURE AND INFECTION
 ASK
 • Ask for mother’s HIV status to establish child’s HIV exposure…reactive, non reactive, unknown.
• Ask if child has had any TB contact.
 LOOK, FEEL AND DIAGNOSE: 
 For child < 18 months
• If mother’s HIV status is unknown, conduct an antibody test (rapid test)on either or mother or child.
• If mother’s or child’s antibody test is POSITIVE the child is HIV exposed. Take DBS for DNA PCR testing at six weeks or earliest contact thereafter
 For child >18 months If Mother is POSITIVE conduct rapid test on child as the child is exposed.

Ask and check record for special treatment needs 

 • Has the mother had within 2 weeks of delivery: 
 		-fever?
 		-infection treated with antibiotic? 

 • Membranes raptured > 18 hours before delivery?
 • Foul smelling liquor?
• Mother tested VDRL positive?
 • Mother tested HIV positive?
 		-Is or has been on ARVs?
 		-Has received infant feeding counselling?
 • Is the mother receiving TB treatment which began < 2 months ago?

IF YES ASK
 		For how long?
 		Is there blood in the stool? 

 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
• Look at the child’s general condition.
Is the child:
			• Lethargic or unconscious?
			• Restless and irritable?
 • Look for sunken eyes. 

• Offer the child fluid. Is the child:
			• Not able to drink or drinking poorly?
			• Drinking eagerly,thirsty? 

• Pinch the skin of the abdomen. Does it go back:
• Very slowly (longer than 2 sec.)?
• Slowly?
• Immediately? 

Classify Diarrhoea

ASK
 • Ask for mother's HIV status to establish child's HIV exposure.Is it: 
 		-Reactive.
 		-Non reactive.
 		-Unknown.
• Ask if child has had any TB contact.

 LOOK,FEEL AND DIAGNOSE: 
 Child ≤ 18 months
• If Mother's HIV status is unknown,conduct an antibody test(rapid test) on mother or child to determine HIV exposure.

•If mother's or child's antibody test is POSITIVE the child is HIV exposed. Take DBS for DNA PCR test at six weeks or earliest contact thereafter.
PRESUMPTIVE SYMPTOMATIC DIAGNOSIS OF HIV INFECTION IN CHILDREN < 18 MONTHS

LOOK and FEEL:
 • Pneumonia***
 • Oral Candidiasis / thrush
 • Severe sepsis.
 • Other AIDS defining conditions**
Presumptive HIV diagnosis should be confirmed at the earliest opportunity. \n\n CLASSIFY HIV STATUS

ASK: 

• Is the infant breastfed?

 IF YES:
-How many times during the day?
-How many times during the night?
-How many times in 24 hours?
 IF NO, why?
• Does the infant usually receive any other foods or drinks?
• How do you prepare the feeds?
• What do you use to feed the infant?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL: 
 Determine weight for age.
• Look for ulcers or white patches in the mouth(thrush).
• Determine mother's HIV status: 
 		-Reactive.
 		-Non reactive.
 		-Unknown.
• Determine HIV exposed Infant's HIV status: 
 	-Positive.
 	-Negative.
 	-Unknown. 

 If the infant has no indications for urgent referral to hospital from previous assessment: 
• Discuss infant feeding options with the mother.

•FOR A MOTHER WHO HAS DECIDED TO BREASTFEED: 
 ASSESS BREASTFEEDING: 
• Has the infant breastfed in the previous hour?
• If the infant has not fed in the previous hour, ask the mother to put her infant to the breast. Observe the breastfeed for 4 minutes.
• (If the infant was fed during the last hour, ask the mother if she can wait and tell you when the infant is willing to feed again.)

 TO CHECK CORRECT POSITIONING, LOOK FOR: 
 -Infant's head and body straight.
 -Infant facing the mother's breast with nose opposite the nipple.
 -Infant's body close to the mother's body.
 -Mother supporting infant's whole body.
 Is the child well positioned?
• Well positioned
• Not well positioned.
 
 TO CHECK ATTACHMENT, LOOK FOR: 
 	-Chin touching breast.
 	-Mouth wide open.
 	-Lower lip turned outward.
 	-More areola visible above than below the mouth.

 (All of these signs should be present if the attachment is good.) 
• Is the infant able to attach?
 	-not well attached.
 	-good attachment.
• Is the infant sucking effectively(that is, slow deep sucks,sometimes pausing)?
 	-not sucking effectively.
 	-sucking effectively.
• Clear a blocked nose if it interferes with breastfeeding.
• Look for ulcers or white patches in the mouth(Thrush).

 Classify FEEDING

ASK:

 		Has the infant had convulsions? 

ASK and LOOK

 		Is the infant not able to feed or breast feed?

 LOOK,LISTEN,FEEL 

• Look for breathing: Is the baby gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated.
• Count the breaths in one minute. Repeat the count if elevated.
• Look for severe chest indrawing .
• Look and listen for grunting or wheezing.
• Look for nasal flaring.
• Look for central cyanosis.
• Look and feel for bulging fontanelle.
• Look for pus draining from the ear.
• Look at the umbilicus. Is it red or draining pus?
• Measure temperature or feel for low or high body temperature.
• Look for skin pustules.
• See if the young infant is drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious.
• Look at the young infant’s movements. IF the infant does not move even when stimulated
• Listen for very high pitched cry.
• Look for stiff neck.
 

Classify ALL YOUNG INFANTS. 

NB: YOUNG INFANT MUST BE CALM.
VERY SEVERE DISEASE
LOCAL BACTERIAL INFECTION
VERY SEVERE DISEASE OR LOCAL BACTERIAL INFECTION UNLIKELY
LOW BODY TEMPERATURE

Any of the following signs:
• Gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated 
• Respiratory rate less than 20 breaths per minute or
• Convulsions or convulsing now or
• Not able to feed or breastfeed or
• Fast breathing (60 breaths per minute or more) or
• Severe chest indrawing or
• Grunting or wheezing or
• Nasal flaring or
• Central cyanosis or
• Bulging fontanelle or
• Pus draining from the ear or
• Fever (37.5°C* or above or feels hot) or
• Very low body temperature(less than 35.5°C* or
• Drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious or
• No movements even when stimulated or
• Very high pitched cry or
• Stiff neck.
• Red umbilicus or draining pus or\n• Skin pustules or.
None of the signs or Very Severe Disease or Local Bacterial Infection
Temperature 35.5°C-36.4°C.

• Immediately resuscitate using a bag and mask if the baby: 

	-Is not breathing at all even when stimulated 
	 or
	-Is gasping or
	 Has a respiratory rate less than 20 breaths per minute.

• If convulsing now, give anticonvulsants.
• Give first dose of Benzylpenicillin & Gentamicin.
• Treat to prevent low blood sugar.
• Advise mother how to keep the infant warm on the way to the hospital.
• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.**

• Give Cotrimoxazole.
• Teach the mother to treat local infections at home.
• Advise mother to give home care for young infant.
• Follow-up in 2 days.
• Advise mother to give home care to the young infant.

• Re-warm young infant and reassess after 1 hour.Read on kangaroo warming.
• Treat to prevent low blood sugar.
• Advise mother to give home care to the young infant.
• Advise mother when to return immediately.

IF YES ASK : 

 • For how long?
 • Is there blood in the stool?

 LOOK,LISTEN,FEEL: 
 Look at the young infant’s general condition.Is the infant: 
	• Lethargic or unconscious?
	• Restless and irritable? 

•Look for sunken eyes.

•Pinch the skin of the abdomen.
Does it go back: 
-	 Very slowly(longer than 2 seconds)?
	- Slowly?
	- Immediately?
 

 NOTE: Remember to classify all infants with Diarrhoea for dehydration
SEVERE DEHYDRATION
SOME DEHYDRATION
NO DEHYDRATION
SEVERE PROLONGED DIARRHOEA

Two of the following signs:
• Lethargic or unconscious
• Sunken eyes
• Skin pinch goes back very slowly

• Restless, irritable
• Sunken eyes
• Drinks eagerly,thirsty
• Skin pinch goes back slowly
• Not enough signs to classify as some or severe dehydration.\n
• Diarrhoea lasting 7 days or more.\n
POSSIBLE SERIOUS ABDOMINAL PROBLEM
• Blood in the stool.

string.name: young_treatment_severe_dehydration
string.b:
If infant also has VERY SEVERE DISEASE:
• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.Advise mother to continue breatfeeding.
• Advice mother to keep the young infant warm on the way to hospital 
	 OR 
• If infant does not have VERY SEVERE DISEASE: Give fluid for severe dehydration (Plan C).
• Give Zinc Sulphate.

resources.string:
If infant also has VERY SEVERE DISEASE:
• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital** with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.
• Advise mother to continue breastfeeding.
• Give fluid and food for some dehydration.
• Give zinc sulphate.

• Give fluids to treat diarrhoea at home (Plan A).
• Give zinc sulphate.
• Advise mother when to return immediately.
• Follow up in 5 days if not improving.

string.name: young_treatment_severe_prolonged_diarrhoea
string.b: • If the young infant is dehydrated, treat dehydration before referral unless the infant has also a VERY SEVERE DISEASE.\n• Admit or refer to hospital.

string.name: young_treatment_severe_abdominal_problem
string.b:
• Give first dose of Benzylpenicillin & Gentamicin.
• Treat the infant/child for or prevent low blood sugar.
• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital**.
• Advise mother how to keep the infant warm on the way.

 Decide Malaria Risk: high, low or no risk. 

 THEN ASK: 
• For how long? 
• If more than 7 days, has fever been present every day? 
• Has the child had signs of measles within the last 3 months?

 LOOK AND FEEL 
 • Look and feel for stiff neck.

Look for signs of MEASLES: 
• Generalized rash and one of these: runny nose, cough or red eyes. 
• Look for any other cause of fever***.


DO A MALARIA TEST: 
If NO general danger sign or stiff neck. 

TEST POSITIVE 
	• P.falciparum PRESENT 
	• P.vivax PRESENT 

TEST NEGATIVE 
	• P.falciparum ABSENT or P.vivax ABSENT 

• High Malaria Risk: Do a malaria test in all fever cases. 

• Low Malaria Risk: Do a malaria test if no obvious cause of fever 

• No Malaria Risk: Do a malaria test if no obvious cause of fever 

NOTE: if you can’t test, don’t withhold treatment 

Classify Fever 


Check for complications of MEASLES 
If the child has signs of measles now or within the last 3 months

FOR ANY SICK CHILD:

Increase fluid. For example: give soup, yoghurt drinks (e.g. Mala), thick encriched uji,madafu or clean water.

 FOR CHILD WITH DIARRHOEA
 Giving extra fluid is life-saving. Give fluid according to Plan A or Plan B on TREAT THE CHILD chart.

• If she has a breast problem(such as engorgement, sore nipples, breast infection), provide care for her or refer her for help.
 • Advise her to express milk from breasts if separated from the baby for more than one day to maintain lactation and prevent breast engorgement.
 • Advise her to eat well to keep up her own strength and health.
 • Encourage male involvement in reproductive and child health care.
 • Check her immunization status including the 5TTs.
 • Check vitamin A status to be given if within 6 weeks of delivery.
\t - Breast examination and Cervical Cancer Screening.\n \t - Family planning.\n \t - Counselling on STI and Reproductive Tract Infection (RTI) prevention.

- Emphasize on importance of early testing for the child and enrollment into HIV care if child is positive.
 	 - Emphasize on the importance of adhering to HIV treatment for both mother and child.
 	 - Refer mother for HIV care and support if services not offered in facility.
 	 - Encourage parent to seek Voluntary Counselling and Testing (VCT).
 	 - Re-emphasize the importance of safe sex and early treatment of STI/RTI and counsel regarding future pregnancies.

- Ask mother about her lochia.
 	 - Ask about perineal care.
 	 - Ask about Caeserian section scar where applicable.

After 2 days 
 • Check the child for general danger signs.
 • Assess the child for cough or difficult breathing.
 Ask: 
 	-Is the child breathing slower?
 	-Is there less fever?
 	-Is the child eating better?

Treatment 
• If chest indrawing or a general danger sign, give a dose of second-line antibiotic or intramuscular chloramphenicol. Then admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital. 

• If breathing rate, fever and eating have not improved, change to the second-line antibiotic and advise the mother to return in 2 days or refer. (If this child had measles within the last 3 months or is known or suspected to have symptomatic HIV infections, refer.) 

• If breathing slower, less fever, or eating better, complete the 5 days of antibiotic.
• Give a dose of second-line antibiotic or intramuscular chloramphenicol. Then admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.\n

• Change to second-line antibiotic and advise the mother to return in 2 days or refer.(If this child had measles within the last 3 months or is known or suspected to have symptomatic HIV infections,refer.)
• Complete the 5 days of antibiotic.

After 2 days
 Assess the child for diarrhoea.
 Ask: 
 	-Are there fewer stools.
 	-Is there less blood in the stool?
 	-Is there less fever?
 	-Is there less abdominal pain?
 	-Is the child eating better?

Treatment:
• If the child is dehydrated, treat dehyration according to classification.
 • If number of stools, amount of blood in stools, fever, abdominal pain, or eating is worse: Admit or refer to hospital.
 • If the condition is the same: add metronidazole to the treatment.
 	 Give it for 5 days. Advise the mother to continue ciproflaxin and zinc and to return in 2 days. Exceptions if the child
 	 1. Is < 12 months old 
	 2. Was dehydrated on the first visit 
	 3. Had measles within the last 3 months 
 For the three Admit or refer urgently to hospital. 
 
 • If fewer stools, less blood in the stools, less fever, less abdominal pain, and eating better, continue giving ciproflaxin and zinc until finished.

After 5 days
 Ask: 
 -Has the Diarrhoea stopped?
 -How many loose stools is the child having per day?

• If the diarrhoea has not stopped(child is still having 3 or more loose stools per day), do a full reassessment of the child.Give any treatment needed. Then refer to hospital.
 • If the diarrhoea has stopped(child having < 3 loose stools per day), tell the mother to follow th usual feeding recommendations for the child's age, but give one extra meal every day 1 month. Ask her to continue giving zinc for total of 10 days.

 • NB: Attention to diet is an essential part of the management of a child with persistent diarrhoea.
• Attention to diet is an essential part of the management of a child with persistent diarrhoea.

• If the diarrhoea has stopped (child having < 3 loose stools per day). Tel the mother to follow the usual feeding recommendations for the child\'s age, but give one extra meal every day 1 month. Ask her to continue giving zinc for total of 10 days.
• If the diarrhoea has not stopped (child is still having 3 or more loose stools per day), do a full reassessment of the child.Give any treatment needed. Then refer to hospital.

After 2 days

 Check the child for general danger signs or chest indrawing
 Assess the child for cough or difficult breathing.

 Ask: 
 	-Is the child breathing slower?
 	-Is the child still wheezing?
 	-Is the child eating better?

Child under 1 year 
• If chest indrawing or a danger sign,fast breathing,poor feeding or wheeze : Give intramuscular antibiotic.Then admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital .
• If breathing slower, no wheezing and eating better continue the treatment for 5 days. 

Child one year and over 
• If chest indrawing or a danger sign give intramuscular antibiotic. Then admit or refer urgently to Hospital.
 • If breathing rate and eating have not improved, change to second line antibiotic, and if still wheezing continue oral bronchodilator. Advise the mother to return in 2 days.
 • If breathing slower,no wheezing and eating better continue the treatment for 5 days.

• If chest indrawing or a danger sign,fast breathing,poor feeding or wheeze : Give intramuscular antibiotic.Then admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital .\n• If breathing slower,no wheezing and eating better continue the treatment for 5 days.

Then admit or refer urgently to Hospital.\n • If breathing rate and eating have not improved, change to second line antibiotic, and if still wheezing continue oral bronchodilator. Advise the mother to return in 2 days.\n • If breathing slower,no wheezing and eating better continue the treatment for 5 days.

• If fever persists after 2 days, or recurs within 14 days: 

• Do a full reassessment of the child. see ASSESS & CLASSIFY chart.
Assess for other causes of fever.

• If the child has any general danger sign or stiff neck, treat as VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE.
 • If the child has any cause of fever other than malaria, provide treatment.
 • If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever: Give Oral DIHYDROARTEMISININ-PIPERAQUINE(DHA-PPQ).Give paracetamol.If child is under 5 kg and was given DHA-PPQ assess further. • Advice mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists 
		 - if the fever has been present every day 7 days,refer for assessment.

• If the child has any cause of fever other than malaria, provide treatment.\n
• If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever: Give Oral DIHYDROARTEMISININ-PIPERAQUINE(DHA-PPQ).Give paracetamol.If child is under 5 kg and was given DHA-PPQ assess further.
• Advice mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists \n\t\t - if the fever has been present every day 7 days,refer for assessment.

If fever persists after 2 days: 

• Do a full reassessment of the child. see ASSESS & CLASSIFY chart.
Assess for other causes of fever.

Treatment: 
• If the child has any general danger sign or stiff neck, treat as VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE.
 • If the child has any cause of fever other than malaria, provide treatment.
 • If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever: 
 		 -Treat with the first-line oral antimalarial. Give paracetamol. Advise the mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists.
 		 -If fever has been present every day for 7 days, refer for assessment.
• If the child has any general danger sign or stiff neck, treat as VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE.
• If the child has any cause of fever other then malaria, provide treatment.\n
• If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever: \n \t\t -Treat with the first-line antimalarial.Give paracetamol.Advise the mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists.\n
\t\t -If fever has been present every day for 7 days, refer for assessment.

After 5 days 

• Reassess for ear problem. > See ASSESS & CLASSIFY chart. 
• Measure the child's temperature.

Treatment

• If there is a tender swelling behind the ear or high fever(38.5°C or above), admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.
• Acute ear infection: If ear pain continues or discharge persists, treat with 5 more days of the same antibiotic. continue wicking to dry the ear.Follow up in 5 days.
• Chronic ear infection: Check that the mother is wicking the ear correctly.Encourage her to continue. Review in 2 weeks.
• If ear discharge continues for more than 2 months: Admit or refer to hospital.
• If no ear pain or discharge, praise the mother for her careful treatment.If she has not yet finished the 5 days of antibiotic, tell her to use it till treatment is completed.
• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.
• If ear pain continues or discharge persists, treat with 5 more days of the same antibiotic. Conitnue wicking to dry the ear.Follow up in 5 days.
• Check that the mother is wicking the ear correctly.Encourage her to continue. Review in 2 weeks.
Admit or refer to hospital.
• Praise the mother for her careful treatment.If she has not yet finished the 5 days of antibiotic, tell her to use it till treatmentis completed.

After 2 days: 
 Look for red eyes and pus draining from the eyes.
 Look at mouth ulcers.
 Smell the mouth.

• If pus is draining from the eye, ask the mother to describe how she has treated the eye infection.
 		-If treatment has been correct, admit or refer to hospital.
 		-If treatment has not been correct, teach mother correct treatment.
 • If the pus is gone but redness remains,continue the treatment.
 • If no pus or redness, stop the treatment.

Treatment for Eye Infection: 

• If pus is draining from the eye, ask the mother to describe how she has treated the eye infection.
 		-If treatment has been correct, admit or refer to hospital.
 		-If treatment has not been correct, teach mother correct treatment.
 • If the pus is gone but redness remains,continue the treatment.
 • If no pus or redness, stop the treatment.

Treatment for Mouth Ulcers: 

• If mouth ulcers are worse, or there is a very foul smell from the mouth, admit or refer to hospital.
 • If mouth ulcers or thrush are the same or better, continue using half-strength gentian voilet or Nystatin for a total of 5 days.
 • If Thrush is no better or is worse consider symptomatic HIV infection.
After 5 days: \n Reassess feeding: See questions at the top of the COUNSEL THE MOTHER. Ask about any feeding problems found on the initial visit.\n

• Counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problems. If you counsel the mother to make significant changes in feeding, ask her to bring the child back after 5 days.\n • If the child is very low weight for age, ask the mother to return 14 days after the initial visit to measure the child\'s weight gain.

After 14 days: 
 • Give iron and folate. Advise mother to return in 14 days for more Iron and Folate.
 • Continue giving Iron and Folate every 14 days for 2 months.
 • If the child has palmar pallor after 2 months, refer for assessment.
After 14 days: \n• Weigh the child and determine if the child is still very low weight for age. Reassess feeding.\n

• If the child is no longer having a very low weight for age, praise the mother and encourage her to continue with the feeding until catch up growth is realized.
• If child is still very low weight for age but gaining weight,encourage the mother to continue with feeding. Counsel the mother about any feeding problem found. Ask the mother to return again in 14 days.
 Continue to see the child every one month until the child is normal weight for age.
• Admit or refer if 

The child has lost weight or is not gaining weight. You do not think that feeding will improve or the child continues to lose weight.
• Praise the mother and encourage her to continue with the feeding until catch up growth is realized.

• If child is still very low weight for age but gaining weight,encourage the mother to continue with feeding. Counsel the mother about any feeding problem found. Ask the mother to return again in 14 days.\n\n Continue to see the child every one month until the child is normal weight for age.
• Child has lost weight. You do not think that feeding will improve or the child continues to lose weight.

HIV INFECTED CHILD 
 After 1 month: 
 • Assess the child's general condition. Do a full reassessment.
 • Treat the child for any condition found.
 • Ask for any feeding problems, counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problems.
 • Advise mother to bring the child back If any new illness develops or she is worried.
 • Counsel the mother or any other problems and ensure community support is being given . Refer for further counselling if necessary.
 • Continue with routine follow up for growth and development, nutrition, immunization, vitamin A, deworming.
 • Assess adherence to ART and Cotrimoxazole and advice accordingly.
 • Offer or refer child for comprehesive HIV management and care (including ART) as per the national ART guidelines.

HIV EXPOSED CHILD (<18 months) :For children tested DNA PCR negative. 
 After 1 months: 
• Assess the child's general condition. Do a full reassessment. 
• Ask for any feeding problems or poor appetite, counsel the mother or continue feeding problems.
 • Treat the child for any condition found.
 • Start or continue with nevirapine prophylaxis.
 • Continue with routine follow up for growth and development,nutrition, immunization, vitamin A, deworming.
 • Screen for TB.
 • Follow up schedule of HIV Exposed infant: 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 6 months, 9months, 12 months, 15 months, 18 months.
 • Refer to early infant Diagnosis (EID) algorithm for confirmation of HIV status.
 • Refer to the HIV exposed infant follow up card and register for further follow up instructions.

After 2 Days: 
 • Look at the umbilicus.Is it red or draining pus?
 • Does redness extend to the skin?
 • Look at the skin pustules. Are there many or severe pustules?
 • Look at the eyes.Is there pus? Is there associated swelling or redness of the eyelids?

• If pus or redness remains or is worse, admit or refer to hospital.
 • If pus and redness are improved, tell the mother to continue giving the 5 days of antibiotic and continue treating the local infection at home. 

 • If the pustules are same or worse, admit or refer to hospital.
 • If skin pustules are improved, tell the mother to continue giving the 5 days of antibiotic and continue treating the local infection at home.
If the child is dehydrated, treat dehydration according to classification.
If number of stools, amount of blood in stools, fever, abdominal pain, or eating is worse: \nAdmit or Refer to hospital.
If the condition is the same : add metronidazole to the treatment.
Exceptions....Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital for the following:
- is child less than 12 months old or
- was dehydrated on the first visit or
- had measles within the last three months
If fewer stools, less blood in the stools, less fever, less abdominal pain, and eating, continue giving ciproflaxin and zinc until finished.

After 2 Days:
Look for jaundice 

-Are palms and soles yellow?

\t\t • If palms and soles are yellow or age 14 days or more, admit or refer to hospital.\n \t\t • If palms and soles are not yellow and age is < 14 days, advise on home care and when to return immediately.

After 2 Days: 
 • Look for pus draining from the eyes.

• If pus is still draining from the eyes, ask the mother to describe how she has treated the eye infection. 
 			 - If treatment has been correct, admit or refer to hospital.
 			 - If treatment has not been correct, teach the mother correct treatment and advise her to give treatment for 5 days. 
Follow up in 2 days. 
		 • If no pus, ask the mother to continue treatment for 5 days.
After 2 Days: \n • Ask if the diarrhoea stopped ?\n
\t\t • If the diarrhoea has not stopped.Assess and treat the young infant for diarrhoea.\n
\t\t • If the diarrhoea has stopped, tell the mother to continue exclusive breastfeeding . Advise her to continue giving zinc to complete 10 days.

After 2 days: 
 Reassess feeding.
 • Ask about any feeding problem found on the initial visit

• Counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problem. If you counsel the mother to make significant changes in feeding, ask her to bring the young infant back after 2 days.
 		 • If the young infant is low weight for age, ask the mother to return 14 days after the initial visit to measure the young infant's weight gain. 

 		 Exception: 
 	If you do not think that feeding will improve, or if the young infant has lost weight, admit or refer the child.
After 2 days\n • Weigh the young infant and determine if the infant is still low weight for age.\n

Reassess feeding.
 		 • If the infant is no longer low weight for age, praise the mother and encourage her to continue, until normal weight is attained. 
		 • If the young infant is still low weight for age, but is feeding well, praise the mother. Ask her to have her infant weighed again within a month or when she returns for immunization. 
• If the infant is still low weight for age and still has a feeding problem, counsel the mother about the feeding problem. Ask the mother to return again in 14 days (or when she returns for immunization, if this is within 2 weeks). Continue to see the young infant every 2 weeks until the infant is feeding well and gaining weight regularly or is no longer low weight for age.

 Exception: 
 If you do not think that feeding will improve, or if the young infant has lost weight, admit or refer to hospital.
Reassess feeding.\n • Praise the mother and encourage her to continue, until normal weight is attained.
• Praise the mother. Ask her to have her infant again within a months or when she returns for immunization.

• Counsel the mother about the feeding problem. Ask her to return again in 14 days (or when she return again for immunization, if this is within 2 weeks). Continue to see the infant every 2 weeks until the infant is feeding well and is gaining weight regularly or is no longer low weight for age.
If you do not think that feeding will improve, or if the young infant has lost weight, admit or refer to hospital.
After 2 days \nLook for ulcers or white patches in the mouth (thrush).\n

Reassess feeding.
 		 •If thrush or mouth ulcers are worse or the infant has problems with attachment or sucking, admit or refer to hospital. 
 		 •If thrush or mouth ulcers are the same or better, and the baby is feeding well continue with Gentian Violet or Nystatin for a total of 5 days.

ASK
 Has the infant had convulsions?
 ASK and LOOK: 
 Is the infant not able to feed or breast feed?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 

 • Look for breathing: Is the baby gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated.
 • Count the breaths in one minute. Repeat the count if elevated.
 • Look for severe chest indrawing .
 • Look and listen for grunting or wheezing.
 • Look for nasal flaring.
 • Look for central cyanosis.
 • Look and feel for bulging fontanel.
 • Look for pus draining from the ear.
 • Look at the umbilicus. Is it red or draining pus?
 • Measure temperature or feel for low or high body temperature.
 • Look for skin pustules.
 • See if the young infant is drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious.
 • Look at the young infant’s movements. Does the infant not move even when stimulated?
 • Listen for very high pitched cry.
 • Look for stiff neck.

CHECK FOR EYE INFECTIONS
 IF YES, ASK: 
 For how long?
 LOOK AND FEEL: 
 • Crossed eyes
• Excessive tearing
• Fear of light
• Clouding of the cornea
• Squeezing of the eyes
• Red eyes
• Whiteness in the pupil
• Eyes discharge, if yes for how long?
• Eyes draining pus
• Swollen eyes

string.name: Plan_A_Counsel_The_Mother
string.b: Counsel the mother on the 4 Rules of Home Treatment: \n\n Give Extra Fluids, Give Zinc Sulphate, Continue Feeding, Advise when to Return

resources.string: 1. GIVE EXTRA FLUID(Give ORS and other fluids- as much as the child will take)\n

• ADVISE THE MOTHER
	-Breastfeed frequently and for longer at each feed.
	-If the child is not exclusively breastfed,give ORS in addition to breast milk.
	-If the child is not exclusively, give one more of the following: ORS solution, food-based fluids(Soup, enriched uji and yoghurt drinks e.g.mala), or safe water.
	-Give fresh fruit juice or mashed bananas to provide potassium.
	-Advise mothers to continue giving ORS as instructed.
• TEACH THE MOTHER HOW TO MIX AND GIVE ORS. GIVE THE MOTHER 4 PACKETS OF ORS TO USE AT HOME.\n

• SHOW THE MOTHER HOW MUCH FLUID TO GIVE IN ADDITION TO THE USUAL FLUID INTAKE: 

 Up to 2 years: 50 to 100 ml after each loose stool.
2 years or more: 100 to 200 ml after each loose stool.
 Advise the mother to: 
 	-Give frequent small sips from a cup.
 	-If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes.Then continue, but more slowly.
 	-Continue giving extra fluids until the diarrhoea stops.
2. GIVE ZINC SULPHATE AND VITAMIN A\n

• TELL THE MOTHER HOW MUCH ZINC SULPHATE TO GIVE: 
	-Up to 6 months: 1/2 tablet per days for 10 days
	-6 months or more: 1 tablet per day for 10 days

• SHOW THE MOTHER HOW TO GIVE ZINC SULPHATE: 
	-Infants: Dissolve the tablet in a small amount of expressed breast milk, ORS or safe water, in a small cup or spoon
	-Older children: Tablets can be chewed or dissolvedin small amounts of ORS or safe.

 REMIND THE MOTHER TO GIVE ZINC SULPHATE FOR THE FULL 10 DAYS

string.name: Plan_B_Give_Four_Hour
string.b: Give in clinic the recommended amount of ORS over 4-hour period

resources.string:
1.DETERMINE AMOUNT OF ORS TO GIVE DURING FIRST 4 HOURS.
 • The appropriate amount of ORS required(in ml) should be calculated by multiplying the child's weight(in kgs) with 75: 
• Use the child's age only when you do not know the weight.
• If the child wants more ORS than shown, give more.
• For infants under 6 months who are not breastfed, also give 100-200 ml clean water during this period.

2.SHOW MOTHER HOW TO GIVE ORS SOLUTION. 
 • Give frequently small sips from a cup(or a spoon every 1-2 minutes for a child under 2 years).
• Check from time to time to see if there are any problems. If the child vomits, wait for 10 minutes then continue but more slowly.
• Continue breastfeeding whenever the child wants.
• If the child's eyelids become puffy, stop ORS and give plain water or breast milk. Give ORS according to plan A when puffiness is gone.

3.AFTER 4 HOURS. 
 • Reassess the child and classify for dehydration.
• Select the appropriate plan to continue treatment.
• Begin feeding the child in the clinic.

4.IF THE MOTHER MUST LEAVE BEFORE COMPLETING TREATMENT: 
 • Show her how to prepare ORS solution at home.
• Show her how much ORS to give to finish 4-hour treatment at home.
• Give her enough ORS satchets to complete rehydration under this plan.Also give her 4 ORS satchets to continue with plan A. Explain the four rules of home treatment.
 		-GIVE EXTRA FLUID.
 		-GIVE ZINC SULPHATE AND VITAMIN A.
 		-CONTINUE FEEDING.
 		-WHEN TO RETURN.

• Explain to the mother why the drug is given.
• Determine the appropriate dose for the child weight(or age).
• Use a sterile needle and sterile syringe. Measure the dose accurately.
• Give the drug as an intramusclular injection.

FOR CHILDREN BEING REFERRED URGENTLY.
 • Give first dose of intramuscular chloramphenicol and refer child to hospital.

 IF REFERRAL IS NOT POSSIBLE: 
 • Treat to prevent hypoglycemia.
• Repeat the chloramphenicol injection every 12 hours for 5 days.
• Then change to an appropriate oral antibiotic to complete 10 days of treatment.
• Give oral chloramphenicol as oral antibiotic if meningitis is highly suspected.
• Give Vitamin A.

• Turn the child to the side and clear the airway.
• Avoid putting things in his/her mouth while he/she is convulsing.
• Give 0.5 mg/kg diazepam injection solution per rectum using a syringe without needle or using a catheter.
• Check the blood sugar level if possible/treat for low blood sugar.
• Repeat diazepam 10 minutes later if still convulsing.
• Give oxygen if available and refer.

string.name: severe_malaria_parenteral
string.i: The recommended treatment for severe malaria is parenteral artesunate, quinine or artemether

resources.string:
• Dissolve artesunic powder with 5%% sodium bicarbonate solution(provided with vial).Dilute resultant solution with 5ml of 5%% dextrose.
• Administer 2.4mg/kg stat by slow IV injection then 1.2mg/kg at 12 hrs and 24 hrs then 1.2 mg/kg daily until the patient is able to tolerate oral medications.
• Artesunate can be given IM at the same dosage and intervals.
• Thereafter a complete course of artemetherlumefantrine (AL) is given.
Touch to view Quinine Dosage Table

• To dilute injection 50mg/ml, draw 5ml of water for injection into a syringe and then draw 1ml of quinine injection 300mg/ml into the same syringe or 3 ml of water for injection and 1 ml of quinine 200mg/ml. Shake gently to mix.

FOR CHILDREN BEING REFERRED WITH VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE: 
• Give first dose of intramuscular quinine(20mg/kg-loading dose) and refer child urgently to hospital.
 IF REFERRAL IS NOT POSSIBLE: 
• Give first dose of IM quinine (20mg/kg-loading dose). The child should remain lying down for one hour.
• Treat to prevent hypoglycemia.
• Repeat the quinine injection every 8 hours(maintenance dose at 10mg/kg) until the child is able to take an oral antimalarial. Do not continue quinine injections for more than 1 week.
• If low risk of malaria, do not give quinine to a child less than 4 months of age.
• Give Vitamin A.

• Administer a loading dose of 3.2mg/kg IM stat then 1.6mg/kg daily until the patient is able to tolerate oral medications.
 • Thereafter a complete course of AL is given.
 • Admit or refer patients with the following: 
 	 • Severe anaemia(Hb level of below 5g/dl or haematocrit of below 15%%)
 	 • Two or more convulsions within a 24-hr period.
 	 • Hyperparasitaemia and are stable. These patients can be treated with AL, DHA-PPQ or oral quinine where ACT is not available. However,they need to be closely monitored.

The recommended treatment for severe malaria is parenteral artesunate, quinine or artemether

 1. Artesunate for Severe Malaria
 • Dissolve artesunic powder with 5%% sodium bicarbonate solution(provided with vial).Dilute resultant solution with 5ml of 5%% dextrose.
• Administer 2.4mg/kg stat by slow IV injection then 1.2mg/kg at 12 hrs and 24 hrs then 1.2 mg/kg daily until the patient is able to tolerate oral medications.
• Artesunate can be given IM at the same dosage and intervals.
• Thereafter a complete course of artemetherlumefantrine (AL) is given.

• To dilute injection 50mg/ml, draw 5ml of water for injection into a syringe and then draw 1ml of quinine injection 300mg/ml into the same syringe or 3 ml of water for injection and 1 ml of quinine 200mg/ml. Shake gently to mix.

Quinine Dilution
 • To dilute quinine injection to 50mg/ml, draw 5ml of water for injection into a syringe and then draw 1ml of quinine injection 300mg/ml into the same syringe or 3 ml water for injection and 1 ml of quinine 200mg/ml. Shake gently to mix. 
 2. Quinine for Severe Malaria
 FOR CHILDREN BEING REFERRED WITH VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE: 
• Give first dose of intramuscular quinine(20mg/kg-loading dose) and refer child urgently to hospital.
 IF REFERRAL IS NOT POSSIBLE: 
• Give first dose of IM quinine(20mg/kg-loading dose). The child should remain lying down for one hour.
• Treat to prevent hypoglycemia.
• Repeat the quinine injection every 8 hours(maintenance dose at 10mg/kg) until the child is able to take an oral antimalarial. Do not continue quinine injections for more than 1 week.
• If low risk of malaria, do not give quinine to a child < 4 months of age.
• Give Vitamin A.

3. Artemether for Severe Malaria
 • Administer a loading dose of 3.2mg/kg IM stat then 1.6mg/kg daily until the patient is able to tolerate oral medications.
 • Thereafter a complete course of AL is given.
 • Admit or refer patients with the following: 
 	 • Severe anaemia(Hb level of below 5g/dl or haematocrit of below 15%%)
 	 • Two or more convulsions within a 24-hr period.
 	 • Hyperparasitaemia and are stable. These patients can be treated with AL, DHA-PPQ or oral quinine where ACT is not available. However,they need to be closely monitored.

• If the child is able to breastfeed
 Ask the mother to breastfeed the child.
 • Is the child is not able to breastfeed but is able to swallow: 
 Give expressed breast milk or a breast milk substitute.
 If neither of these is available give sugar water.
 Give 30-50 ml of milk or sugar water before departure.

 To make sugar water : Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20grams) in a 200 ml cup 
• If the child is not able to swallow: 
 Give 50 ml of milk or sugar water by nasogastric tube.
 For suspected low blood sugar
 Give 10%% glucose 5ml/kg by nasogastric tube OR 
 Give the same amount slowly intravenously if a line is available.
 Keep warm.
 Admit or Refer urgently to hospital
 Low blood sugar(hypoglycemia) may be suspected in any infant or child who is convulsing or has loss of consciousness for which there is no obvious cause; has a rectal temperateure of below 35.5°C is drowsy or sweating, is lethargic, floppy or jittery particularly when less than 2 months old.

 To constitute 10%% glucose from 50%% glucose: Mix 1 part of 50%% glucose with 4 parts of water for injection.
Ask the mother to breastfeed the infant.\n
Give 20-50ml (10ml/kg) expressed breast milk and of not available, give 20-50 ml (10ml/kg) sugar water before referral.\n
Give 20-50 ml (10ml/kg)expressed breast milk or sugar water by nasogastric tube(NG tube).
Give 10%% glucose 10ml/kg by nasogastric tube give same amount slowly intravenously. (To make 10%% glucose mix one part of 50%% glucose with 4 parts water for injection)
Admit or Refer urgently to hospital

resources.string: Ask the mother to breastfeed the child.\n
Give expressed breast milk or a breast milk substitute. If neither of these is available, give sugar water. Give 30-50 ml of milk or sugar water before departure.
Give 50 ml of milk or sugar by nasogastric tube.
Give 10%% glucose** 5 ml/kg by nasogastric tube OR \n Give same amount slowly intravenously if a line is available. keep warm.

string.name: old_admitorRefer
string.b: Admit or Refer urgently to hospital

resources.string: - Low blood sugar(hypoglycemia) may be suspected in any infant or child who is convulsing or has loss of consciousness for which there is no obvious cause; has a rectal temperature of below 35.5°C, is drowsy or sweating, is lethargic, floppy or jittery- particularly when < 2 months old\n\n - To constitute 10%% glucose from 50%% glucose: Mix 1 part of 50%% glucose with 4 parts of water for injection.
• A baby who is gasping or not breathing at all will require resuscitation.

• Place the baby onto a firm, clean and warm surface.\n • Inform the mother that the baby has difficulty breathing and that you will help the baby breathe.\n • Keep the baby wrapped and under a radiant heater if possible.

• Position the head so that it is slightly extended.
 • Suction the mouth and then the nose.
 • Introduce the suction tube into the newborn's mouth 5cm from lips and suck while withdrawing.
 • Introduce the suction tube 3cm into each nostril and suck while withdrawing until no mucus.
 • Repeat each suction if necessary but no more than twice and no more than 20 seconds in total.

• Place mask to cover chin, mouth and nose.
 • Form seal.
 • Squeeze bag attached to the mask with 2 fingers or whole hand, according to bagsize, 2 or 3 times
 • Observe rise of chest. If chest not rising : 
 			• Reposition head.
 			• Check mask heal.
 			• Squeeze bag harder.
 • Once good seal and chest rising, ventilate at 40 squeezes per minute until baby starts breathing spontaneously.

• Look at the chest for indrawing.
 • Count breaths per minute.
 • If breathing more than 30 breaths per minute and no severe chest drawing: 
 			• Do not ventilate any more.
 			• Put the baby in skin to skin contact on mother's chest and continue care.
 			• Monitor every 15 minutes for breathing and warmth.
 			• Tell the mother that the baby will probably be well.
DO NOT LEAVE THE BABY ALONE\n

• Continue ventilating.
 • Arrange for immediate referral.
 • Explain to the mother what has happened,what are you doing and why?
 • Ventilate during referral.
 • Record the event on the referral form .
• Stop ventilating, the baby is dead.\n • Explain to the mother and give supportive care.\n • Record the event.
Evaluate the baby\'s breathing after stimulation: \n • A baby who is gasping or not breathing at all will require resuscitation.

Keep the baby warm
• Place the baby onto a firm, clean and warm surface.
 • Inform the mother that the baby has difficulty breathing and that you will help the baby breathe.
 • Keep the baby wrapped and under a radiant heater if possible.

Open the airway
 • Position the head so that it is slightly extended.
 • Suction the mouth and then the nose.
 • Introduce the suction tube into the newborn's mouth 5cm from lips and suck while withdrawing.
 • Introduce the suction tube 3cm into each nostril and suck while withdrawing until no mucus.
 • Repeat each suction if necessary but no more than twice and no more than 20 seconds in total.

If still no breathing, ventilate
• Place mask to cover chin, mouth and nose.
 • Form seal.
 • Squeeze bag attached to the mask with 2 fingers or whole hand, according to bagsize, 2 or 3 times
 • Observe rise of chest. If chest not rising : 
 			• Reposition head.
 			• Check mask heal.
 			• Squeeze bag harder.
 • Once good seal and chest rising, ventilate at 40 squeezes per minute until baby starts breathing spontaneously.

If breathing or crying, stop ventilating
 • Look at the chest for indrawing.
 • Count breaths per minute.
 • If breathing more than 30 breaths per minute and no severe chest drawing: 
 			• Do not ventilate any more.
 			• Put the baby in skin to skin contact on mother's chest and continue care.
 			• Monitor every 15 minutes for breathing and warmth.
 			• Tell the mother that the baby will probably be well. 

 DO NOT LEAVE THE BABY ALONE

If breathing less than 30 breaths per minute or severe chest indrawing:
 • Continue ventilating.
 • Arrange for immediate referral.
 • Explain to the mother what has happened,what are you doing and why?
 • Ventilate during referral.
 • Record the event on the referral form .

If no breathing or gasping at all after 20 minutes ventilation 
 • Stop ventilating, the baby is dead.
 • Explain to the mother and give supportive care.
 • Record the event.

KEEP THE YOUNG INFANT WARM
 • Warm the young infant using skin to skin contact: Kangaroo Mother Care
 	- Provide privacy to the mother. If mother is not available, skin to skin contact can be provided by the father or any other adult.
 	- Request the mother to sit or recline comfortably.
 	- Undress the baby gently, except for cap,nappy and socks.
 	- Ask the mother to wear light, loose clothing that is comfortable inthe ambient temperature, and can accommodate the young infant.
 	- Place the young infant on the mother's chest prone in an upright and extended posture, between her breasts in skin contact; turn the baby's head to one side and keep always clear.
 	- Ensure that the young infant's feet and elbows are flexed into a frog-like position and the head and chest are on the mother's chest, with the head in a slighty extended position.
 	- cover the infant with mother's clothes; wrap the mother-baby duo with an added blanket or shawl.
 	- After positioning the young infant, allow mother to rest with the young infant.
 	- Breast feed the young infant frequently.
 	- If possible, warm the room above 25°C with a heating device.

• If skin to skin contact is not possible: \n \t- If radiant warmer is available use it warm the young infant or.\n \t- Warm the room 25°C with heating device and clothe the young infant in 3-4 layers of warm clothes, cover the head with a cap(include gloves and socks) and cover with a blanket or shawl.
• Reassess after 1 hour: \n \t- Assess for signs of Very Severe Disease.\n \t- Measure axillary temperature by placing the thermometer in the axillary for 5 minutes(or feel for low body temperature)
• If any signs of "very severe disease" or temperature still 36.5°C.\n \t- Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital after giving pre-referral treatment for "Very Severe Disease".

• If no signs of "very severe disease" or temperature still 36.5°C.
 	- Advise how to keep the young infant warm at home.
 	- Advise mother to give home care.
 	- Advise mother when to return immediately.

Teach the Mother How to Keep the Young Infant Warm on the way To the Hospital\n • Provide skin to skin contact OR \n • Keep the infant clothed or covered as much as possible all the time. Dress the young infant in 3-4 layers of clothes(including hat, gloves, socks) and wrap him/her in a soft dry cloth and cover with shawl or blanket. Hold the baby close to your body.

GIVE THESE TREATMENT IN HEALTH FACILITY ONLY 
 • Explain to the mother why the drug is being given.
 • Determine the dose appropriate for the infant's weight(or age).
 • Use a sterile needle and sterile syringe to accurately measure the dose.
 • Do not mix benzyl penicillin with Gentamicin.
 • Give the drug as intramuscular injection.
 • If the infant cannot be referred, follow instructions provided in the section Where Referral is not Possible found below the table on the right.

Follow the instructions below for every oral drug to be given at home.
 Also follow the instructions listed with each drug's dosage table.
 • Determine the appropriate drugs and dosage for the child's age or weight.
 • Tell the mother the reason for giving the drug to the child.
 • Demonstrate how to measure a dose.
 • Watch the mother practise measuring a dose by herself.
 • Ask the mother to give the first dose to her child.
 • Explain carefully how to give the drug, then label and package the drug.
 • If more than one drug will be given, collect, count and package each drug separately.
 • Explain that all oral drug tablets or syrups must be used to finish the course of treatment, even if the child gets better.
 • Check the mother's understanding before she leaves the clinic.

• Explain how the treatment is given.
 • Watch her as she does the first treatment in the clinic.
 • She should return to the clinic if the infection worsens.
 • Check the mother's understanding before she leaves the clinic.

To Treat Skin Pustules or Umbilical Infection
 Apply Gentian Violet twice daily.
 The mother should: 
 	• Wash hands.
 	• Gently wash off pus and crusts with soap and water.
 	• Dry the area.
 	• Paint with gentian voilet.
 	• Wash hands

To Treat Thrush(white patches in mouth)or Mouth Ulcers
 The mother should: 
 	• Wash hands.
 	• Wash mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water.
 	• Paint the mouth with half-strength gentian voilet or instill Nystatin.
 	• Wash hands.
 If breastfed, advise the mother to wash her breast after feeds and apply the same medicine on the areola.

Treat Eye Infection with Tetracycline Eye Ointment
 • Clean both eyes 3 times daily.
 		• Wash hands.
 		• Use clean cloth and water to gently wipe away pus.
 • Then apply tetracycline eye ointment in both eyes 3 times daily.
 		• Open the eyes of the young infant.
 		• Squirt a small amount of ointment on the inside of the lower lid.
 		• Wash hands again.
 • Treat until redness is gone.
 • Do not use other eye ointments or drops,or put anything else in the eye.

Teach Correct Positioning and Attachment for Breastfeeding
 • Show the mother how to hold her infant.
 		- with the infant's head and body her straight.
 		- facing her breast, with infant's nose opposite her nipple.
 		- with infant's body close to her body.
 		- supporting infant's whole body, not just neck and shoulders.

 • Show her how to help the infant to attach. She should: 
 		- touch her infant's lips with her nipple.
 		- wait until her infant's mouth is opening wide.
 		- move her infant quickly ontoher breast, aiming the infant's lower lip well below the nipple.

 • Look for signs of good attachment and effective suckling. If attachment or suckling is not good, try again.

 • If still not suckling effectively, ask the mother to express breast milk and feed with cup in the clinic.

 • If able to feed with a cup advise mother to continue breastfeeding the infant and at the end of each feed express breast milk and feed a cup.
 • If not able to feed with a cup, Admit or Refer to hospital.

Teach the Mother to treat breast or nipple problems

 • If the nipple is flat or inverted, evert the nipple several times with fingers before each feed and put the baby on the breast.

 • If the nipple is sore, apply breast milk for soothing effect and ensure correct positioning and attachment of the baby. If mother continues feeling discomfort feed expressed breast milk with cup.

 • If breasts are engorged, let the baby continue to suck if possible. If the baby cannot suckle effectively, help the mother to express the milk and then put the young infant to the breast. Putting warm compress on the breast may help.

 • If breasts abscess, advice the mother to feed from the other breast then admit or refer to hospital. If the young infant wants more milk give appropriate formula milk using a cup.

Teach the mother how to keep the young infant with low weight or low body temperature warm at home:
 • Do not bathe young infant with low weight or body temperature; instead sponge with lukewarm water to clean(in a warm room).
 • Provide skin to skin contact(Kangaroo mother care)as much as possible, day and night.
 • When not in skin to skin contact or if this is not possible,
 	- Warm the room (>25°C) with a home heater.
 	- Clothe the young infant in 3-4 layers of warm clothes, cover the head with a cap(include gloves and socks) and wrap him/her in a soft dry cloth and cover with a warm blanket or shawl.
 	- Let the baby and mother lie together on a soft, thick bedding.
 	- Change clothes(e.g. napkins) whenever they are wet.

 FEEL THE FEET OF THE BABY PERIODICALLY --BABY'S FEET SHOULD BE ALWAYS WARM TO TOUCH

Treat the Young Infant to prevent Low Blood Sugar
 • If the infant is able to breastfeed: Ask the mother to breastfeed the infant.
 • If not able to breastfeed but is able to swallow: Give 20-50 ml (10ml/kg) expressed breast milk and if not available, give 20-50 ml (10ml/kg) sugar water before referral. 
 To make sugar water: Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20 grams) in a 200-ml cup of clean water.
 • If the child is not able to swallow: Give 20-50ml(10ml/kg) expressed breast milk or sugar water by NG tube.
 • If low blood sugar is suspected: Give 10%% glucose 10ml/kg by nasogastric tube give same amount intravenously.
 * Low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) may be suspected in any infant there is no obvious cause; has a rectal temperature of below 35.5°C is drowsy or sweating, is lethargic, floppy of jittery.

• FOOD
• FLUIDS
• WHEN RETURN
• MAKE SURE THE YOUNG INFANT STAYS AT ALL TIMES.
 
		AFASS(Affordable, Feasible,Acceptable, Sustainable and Safe) In cool weather, cover the infant's head and feet and dress the infant with extra clothing.
 • Breastfeed frequently, as often and for long as the infant wants, day or night, during sickness and health.
 • If baby cannot be breastfed, counsel on alternative feeding.

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for HIV-positive women for the first 6 months of life unless exclusive replacement feeding is acceptable, feasible, affordable, sustainable and safe.\n After 6 months, appropriate complementary feeds should be introduced and breastfeeding continued for the first year of life of the infant. Thereafter, breastfeeding may be stopped gradually if a nutritionally acceptable and safe diet can be provided.

Exclusive replacement feeding involves giving the baby only commercial breast milk substitutes.Exclusive replacement is recommended if AFASS(Affordable, Feasible, Acceptable, Sustainable and Safe) criteria is met

• Exclusive breastfeeding, giving breast milk only, for 6 months is the best way to feed her baby whether she is HIV positive or not.
•Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for HIV Positive mothers unless formula is AFASS(Affordable, Feasible,Acceptable, Sustainable and Safe)
• If mother chooses to breastfeed, she will be provided with medication to reduce the chance of infecting her infant during breastfeeding period.
•mixed feeding (giving breast milk and other milks, water and foods before six months increases the risk of transmitting HIV to her infant and the risk of diarrhoea and other illnesses)
•At 6 months her child needs nutritions locally available family foods in addition to breast milk. 

 Infant Feeding Options
 Inform the mother of the two main recommended infant feeding options for HIV-exposed infants:

Make sure that the mother or caretaker understands that mixed feeding (giving breast milk and other milks, water and foods) before 6 months increases the risk of transmitting HIV to the infant and the risk of death from diarrhoea and other illnesses.
 
 	 • Reinforce exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, Initiation of breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth, Emphasize on positioning, attachment care of the breast and management of breast conditions.
	• Advice the mother to introduce appropriate complementary feeds from age six months while continuing to breast feed up to 12 months or beyond.
	• Advice mother that breastfeeding should stop once a nutritionally adequate and safe diet without breast milk can be provided.
	• Emphasize on adherence to ARVs.

The mother/caregiver should have received full counselling before making the decision not to breastfeed.
 
 	• Give information on replacement feeding and the risk of mixed feeding.
	• Give information on safe preparation, storage and appropriate feeding techniques for chosen artificial feeds.
	• Demonstrate on how to prepare and feed the infant.
	•Counsel on care of the breast to avoid engorgement.
	•Provide reliable family planning.
	•For low birth weightbabies(1.5kg)and pre-term babies advise on special infant formula.
	•Adhere to the code of marketing of breast milk substitutes.
	• HIV- exposed infants not breastfeeding should be given ART prophylaxis for 6 weeks only.

string.name: mother_reports_difficulty
string.b: • If the mother reports difficulty with breastfeeding, assess breastfeeding as needed,show the mother correct positioning and attachment for breastfeeding.

resources.string: \t- Build mother\'s confidence that she can produce all the breast milk that the child needs.\n \t- Suggest giving more frequent, longer breastfeeds day or night,and gradually reducing other milk or foods.

- Breastfeed as much as possible, including at night.
 	- Make sure that other milk is a locally appropriate breast milk substitute.
 	- Make sure other milk is correctly and hygienically prepared and given in adequate amounts
 	- Make sure that left over feeds are not fed to the baby.

- Recommend reinstating breastfeeding if possible
 	- Recommend substituting a cup for bottle.
 	- Show the mother how to feed the child with a cup
 	- Re emphasize hand washing and hygiene.
\t- Sit with the child and encourage eating.\n \t- Give the child an adequate serving in a separate plate or bowl.

- Clear a blocked nose if it interferes with feeding.
 	- Breastfeed more frequently and for longer if possible.
 	- For the child under 6 months who is not breastfed, increase the number of milk feeds.
 	- For a child already on complementary feeds,give soft,varied,appetizing,enriched favoritefoods including milk to encourage the child to eat as much as possible.
 	- Offer small frequent feeds.
 	- Give snacks between meals and check regularly for oral thrush or ulcers.
 	- Expect that appetite will improve as child gets better.

- Counsel the mother to make informed decision either to breastfeed exclusively or give replacement feeding.
 	- If she chooses to exclusively breastfeed, build her confidence and counsel as above.
 	- If she chooses replacement feeding, counsel her as in recommendation during feeding 
 	- Make her understand that mixed feeding increases the risk of HIV transmission through breast milk.

string.name: child_being_cared
string.b: • If the child is not being cared for as described on page 20. Counsel the caregiver accordingly.In addition:

resources.string: Hold the child close when feeding, look at the child, and talk or sing to him/her.
\t - Inform her/him that children play and communicate from birth.\n \t - Demonstrate for her/him how the child responds to activities.
\t - Combine care for development with other care for the child(feeding, bathing, dressing).\n \t - Ask other family members to help provide care for development or help her/him with other tasks.
\t - Use any household objects that are clean and safe.\n \t - Make simple toys.\n \t - Play with the child, as the child will learn by playing with her/him and other people.

- Encourage the caregiver to do extra care for development activities.
 	 - Check to see whether the child is able to see and to hear.
 	 - Refer the child with difficulties seeing or hearing to special services.
 	 - Encourage the caregiver and other family members to play and communicate with the child through touch movement.

\t - Identify at least one person who can care for the child regularly and give the child love and attention.\n \t - Expect that, with love and special attention, the child can recover from the loss of a parent.\n

• If the child cannot be breastfed, counsel the Caregiver to:

• If the caregiver does not know what his/her child does to play or communicate:

• If the caregiver feels he/she does not have enough time to provide care for development, encourage him/her to:

• If the caregiver has no toys for the child to play with, counsel the caregiver to:

• If the child is not responding, or seems "slow":

• If the child being raised by someone other than the mother, help the caretaker to:

• Follow-up any feeding problem in 5 days.• Follow-up any feeding problem in 5 days.

b.u: When to return to a health worker or health facility:

resources.string:
• Recommend soft foods that will not burn the mouth such as thick enriched porridge, eggs, mashed potatoes, bananas, pumpkin or avocado.
• Chop foods finely.
• Avoid salty, spicy; acidic foods that may irritate the child.
• Give cold nutritious drinks- they'll not make the child sick or sicker.
